newsitem.title: GREECE: Greek archaeology watchdog slams Virgin hotel plan.
newsitem.headline: Greek archaeology watchdog slams Virgin hotel plan.

text.p: Greece's top archaeology watchdog on Wednesday rejected plans by British entrepreneur Richard Branson's Virgin Group to build a hotel resort on the historic island of Hydra where no cars are allowed.
The powerful Central Archaeological Council (KAS) said in a decision issued on Wednesday the hotel complex would alter the character of the Hydra village of Kaminia.
"We believe the positioning and construction of buildings would cause immediate damage to the historic, preserved settlement by altering its perimeter and character," KAS said.
Although its role technically is only advisory, KAS decisions are never contradicted by the culture minister, who has the final say.

Branson's Virgin Hellas Hotel company envisioned a romantic complex of buildings, with winding paths, swimming pools and tennis courts on the island, which is a 90-minute hovercraft ride from the main Greek port of Piraeus.

Environmentalists and cultural preservation societies campained against the proposed 5,000 square-metre project, but islanders appeared before KAS to support the plan, saying it would create more than 100 permanent and 300 seasonal jobs.

"The island's 2,600 remaining residents are distressed at the decision. They feel the state wants to turn the island into a deserted archaeological site," Hydra mayor Constantine Anastopoulos was quoted as saying by the semi-official Athens News Agency.
Kaminia, a small village west of Hydra's port town can only be reached by mule path. Hydra is popular with Greeks but has been spared a mass onslaught of back-packers because of its rocky beaches.

KAS did not totally shut the door in Branson's face, saying it would consider a new proposal for a much smaller hotel complex within the perimeter of the village, provided it did not include new roads, swimming pools, or sports facilities.

"Within the limits of the Kamini settlement and especially in the southern section of his property, a study on facilities for similar use may possibly be seen positively," KAS said after a six-hour meeting to consider Branson's proposal.
